1123350409169575936.text: 16/ Similarly, if you have $50k in savings, putting half of it in Bitcoin would indeed be "too risky" for you.  But putting 1% of that into BTC isn't.  Putting 1% of that into BTC probably *reduces* the risk of your total portfolio because it's diversifying.

1123350155216945152.text: 15/ an investment in the S&P 500 index (500 of the largest US stocks), is not a vote of confidence in each and everyone of those 500 stocks.  No - any one of those stocks might be super risky, but as a diversified basket of 500 equities, the risk is much lower.

1123347387072811009.text: 4/ Let's consider stocks vs Bitcoin.  We can measure risk in many different ways, let's use annualized volatility as our metric just so we can apply some numbers.  Let's say stocks have annual volatility of 20% and Bitcoin of 80%.

1123347157015257099.text: 3/ Example:  Asset A is twice as risky as Asset B.  Asset A also has 4x the expected return as asset B.  Which is riskier? 1083018747491823616.text: 10/ Treat your savings account number as a private key that's never divulged.  Of course the big banks have horrible data security so this information might get stolen from the bank, but at least you're not literally handing the info to everyone when you give them checks.

1083018452753895424.text: 9/ So, view your checking account as a "hot wallet" or physical wallet.  Keep minimal amounts there.  Most of your cash should be in a separate account (savings accounts are usually easy, brokerage accounts are safer), and never send money directly from those.

1045435832889483264.text: 8/ I DO NOT suggest buying out of the money options.  Again, unless you have professional experience trading options, best to steer clear.

1045435715729920000.text: 7/ When buying an out of the money option, you should *expect* to lose the entire investment.  So why buy it?  Because if it pays off, it may pay you 5 to 1, or better.  A 40% chance of making a 5:1 return is a great bet.

1045435501048737792.text: 6/ If you are a profitable ongoing buyer of out of the money options, you may lose the entirety of the investment 90% of the time.  That's fine, as long as each bet is only a small % of your trading capital.

1045435355040829446.text: 5/ But it's also worth noting that there's no shame in losing trades.  Active traders typically aim to win on ~55% of their trades.  The key is risk management.  An out of the money option is very likely to lose 100% of its value, or return a multiple of its value.
